Core Course: Macroeconomic Management: New Methods and Current Policy Issues
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Natalie Deveaux Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-1399
Number 16 September 1998
Agenor, Pierre-Richard; Denizer, Cevdet (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
A course on macroeconomic management was held in Ankara, Turkey, from July 7-17, 1998, by the Economic Development Institute (EDI). The background work that led to the development of this course showed that stability enhancing policies and policies that help to secure investment can lead to a reduction in the incidence of poverty. Therefore, this course aimed to promote those kinds of macroeconomic policies through two primary course objectives. First, it aimed to improve participant ability to investigate, debate and formulate policies related to macroeconomic issues. The second goal was to facilitate the transfer of macroeconomic knowledge to a wider audience through participant-trainers and participating training institutions. To accomplish these goals, the course reviewed current analytical and methodological advances in the field of development macroeconomics in Turkey, the Middle East, and transition economies. The targeted audience was the World Bank staff, policy advisors in government, university professors, and researchers.
An evaluation was done by the EDI Evaluation Unit (EDIES) covering several aspects of the course. A set of cognitive questions was randomly assigned to pre-test and post-test groups. These questions were administered at the beginning and end of the course, and were used to measure learning gain as a result of the course. Participants were asked to give their opinion about the course objectives, relevance, content, timing, delivery and faculty. Participants were also asked to assess how much they had learned on selected topics from the course. All questions on the evaluation used a 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1=minimum to 5=maximum. Results from the evaluation are summarized below.
l Of 24 participants, 19 (74%) responded to the questionnaire. Demographic information was limited, however it did show that there was a relatively high number of female participants (11 of 19 respondents, 58%) in the course.
l The evaluation questionnaire asked participants for their opinions about items falling into 6 categories. The category that received the most favorable responses addressed the relevance of the course. For the 3 questions covering relevance, the range of mean scores was 4.05 to 4.63 on a 5 point scale. An evaluation of the same core course, held earlier in Washington D.C. also showed that participants found the course highly relevant. For that course, the mean scores ranged from 4.33 to 4.39 out of 5.
l Items related to the delivery of the course also received mean scores in the high range (4.00 to 4.58). These results show that respondents were highly satisfied with the way in which the course content was conveyed, including the presentation, materials, examples and teaching aids. This is especially important as one of the objectives of the course was to train participants to present the course content to a wider audience in the future.  lThe category of items that received the lowest range of mean scores was that of time and sequencing (3.63 to 3.84). The four items in this category asked if the work load was adequate (mean=3.84), if topics were effectively balanced (mean=3.63), if they were covered in sufficient depth (mean=3.84) and if there was adequate time for discussion (3.74). Written comments suggest that some participants found the course demanding, and would have appreciated an extra day of class.
lThe VAR segment of the course achieved the largest perceived knowledge gains. The scores for the VAR techniques and applications changed from 2.53 before the course to 4.00 after the course, an increase of 1.47 (58%).
lThe item covering the topics of consumption, saving and investment received the least favorable pre/post change score (.42). However, this does not necessarily indicate a weakness in teaching method. Since the pre-course mean for this item (3.79) was the highest pre-course mean of all the self-assessment questions, it may be that the participants were more knowledgeable on these issues and consequently, that the course material could have started at a more advanced level.
lResults from the randomly assigned cognitive questions showed little gain in this area by participants. The average (mean) number of correct answers on the pretest was 7.24 out of 13, or 55.7%. Compared to other EDI courses that have used this method, this is a relatively high pretest score, suggesting that participants may have been more knowledgeable about the material than is the case in these other courses. The post-test score was 7.40, or 56.9% correct, a gain of slightly more than 1%. A t-test was conducted to measure the pre/post-test difference. The t-value with 30 degrees of freedom was -0.176, which was not statistically significant (p = .861). Higher pre-test scores may have been a factor in the inability of this test to detect a change.
